Section 3 focuses on the Methane Hydrate Research and Development Program. The Methane Hydrate Research and Development Act of 2000 mandates the commencement of a program within 180 days, with designated individuals coordinating activities and meeting within 270 days. The Methane Hydrate Research and Development Act of 2000 requires regular meetings to review program progress and make recommendations for future activities. The Secretary may award grants or contracts for research on methane hydrate as an energy source. The Act aims to develop technologies for efficient and environmentally sound methane hydrate resource development, safe transport and storage of methane, education and training in methane hydrate research, assessment and mitigation of environmental impacts, risk reduction in drilling through methane hydrates, and exploratory drilling support. Funding is subject to competitive merit-based review. The Secretary will establish an advisory panel of experts to advise on methane hydrate applications, research priorities, and climate change impacts. Funding will be based on a competitive merit-based process. The advisory panel will focus on methane hydrate degassing and natural gas consumption. Federal employees will make up no more than 25 percent of the panel. Limitations include a 5 percent cap on administrative expenses and restrictions on using funds for construction projects. The Secretary is responsible for developing partnerships, conducting research on methane hydrate resources, promoting long-term interest in methane hydrate as an energy source, ensuring data accessibility, promoting cooperation among agencies, and reporting accomplishments to Congress annually. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS TO THE MINING AND MINERALS POLICY ACT OF 1970. Section 201 of the Mining and Minerals Policy Act of 1970 is amended to include methane hydrate as a defined term, describing it as a methane clathrate found in deep-ocean and permafrost areas. Authorization of appropriations for the Secretary of Energy under this Act: $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2001, $7,500,000 for fiscal year 2002, $11,000,000 for fiscal year 2003, $12,000,000 for fiscal year 2004, and $12,000,000 for fiscal year 2005. Amounts authorized remain available until expended. Section 3 of the Act will no longer be effective after fiscal year 2005. Additionally, a National Research Council study is mandated. The Secretary will contract the National Research Council to study progress and future needs of methane hydrate research. A report with findings and recommendations must be submitted to Congress by September 30, 2004. The Secretary of Energy must provide the House Committee on Science with copies of any reports or studies directed by Congress.
